results.title: Espana Viva [kit]
results.brief_description: A kit for the “Espana viva” Spanish course for beginners consisting of two audio-cassettes divided into 15 units that correspond to the dialogues in the student text together with pronunciation practice and exercises. Included is a copy of the student text and teacher’s notes.

results.title: Eskimo children
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: A study of an Eskimo family living on Nunivak Island, off the Alaskan coast, showing how the Eskimo people solve the problem of providing food, clothing, shelter, and transport for themselves. Today the results of the contacts made with the outside world can be seen in the changing customs of the Eskimo people.

results.title: Eskimo artist: Kenojouac
results.creator_credit: John Feeney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Beautiful Inuit prints by an artist who is also a wife and mother. This film shows how the Inuit artist’s drawings are transferred to stone and then printed for sale in the south.

results.title: Escape to Witch Mountain
results.creator_credit: John Hough, Jerome Courtland and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.brief_description: Two orphans develop telekinetic powers and escape from exploitative adults with the aid of a grieving widow. They retreat to Witch Mountain, discovering their powers, which include predicting the future, levitating objects and mastery over animals. This extremely popular family oriented children’s film features Eddie Albert, Ray Milland, and Donald Pleasence, with Kim Richards and Ike Eisenmann, playing the imperilled children.

results.title: Escape from Woomera
results.brief_description: Escape from Woomera is a videogame that asks players to experience Australia’s draconian immigration policies from the point-of-view of a refugee. By combining game mechanics, art and activism, Escape from Woomera goes beyond the razor wire and detention centre media blackout.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

results.description:
If you thought escaping from Castle Wolfenstein was hard, try Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre…

With a first person, 3D adventure game we invite gamers to assume the character of, and ‘live’ through the experiences of a modern day refugee. The effective media lock-out from immigration detention centres has meant that the whole truth about what goes on behind the razor-wire at Woomera, Baxter, Port Hedland, Maribyrnong and Villawood remains largely a mystery to the Australian public. We want to challenge this by offering the world a glimpse - more than that even: an interactive, immersive experience - of life within the most secretive and controversial places on the Australian political and geographical landscape. In this way, Escape From Woomera will be an engine for mobilising experiences and situations otherwise inaccessible to an nation of disempowered onlookers. It will provide both a portal and a toolkit for reworking and engaging with what is otherwise an entirely mediated current affair.

It will provide both a portal and a toolkit for reworking and engaging with what is otherwise an entirely mediated current affair.

results.title: Escape from the sea
results.creator_credit: Peter Seabourne, A. Frank Bundy and Wallace Productions
results.brief_description: A film designed for a youthful audience depicting the adventures of a boy about 12 years old who gets into difficulty in the sea in his rubber dingy. He is rescued by a scouting group who then have problems when their leader is hit by falling rocks. He in turn is rescued by helicopter. Filmed on the foreshores of Cornwall this is a “safety” film showing the work of the Royal Naval Rescue Service and HM Coastguard.

results.title: Escape from Sobibor
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, Dennis E. Doty, Zenith Productions and Rule-Starger Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Richard Rashke, and unpublished manuscripts From the ashes of Sobibor” by Thomas Blatt and “Inferno in Sobibor by Stanislaw Szmajzner, this made for television (originally as a miniseries) drama tells the true story of a heroic escape by Jewish prisoners in the Nazi death camp in the forests of Sobibor, a Polish village, in October 1943. During the camp’s operation from May 1942 to October 1943, approximately 250,000 Polish and Russian Jews were exterminated in the five gas chambers - only the skilled survived to work as labourers under the watchful and often brutal Nazi guards. But even those who did survive knew they were on borrowed time. Escape was the only answer. The traumatised prisoners, led by Leon Feldhendler (Alan Arkin) along with the support of the prisoners of war Russian soldiers under the command of Alexander Percherski (Rutger Hauer), hatch a fantastic plan of escape. However, this ambitious plan is not just for a handful of prisoners, it is a chance for all 600 prisoners to make a bid for freedom and survival. This uprising proved to be the largest and most successful of its kind during World War II. For forty years the world was unaware of the events - the Nazis destroyed the camp and all of its records in a cover-up by burning it to the ground. An intense human drama displaying some of the brutality, but also the determination, spirit and courage of those who survived the Holocaust and this most amazing escape. Cast also includes Joanna Pacula, Hartmut Becker, Simon Gregor and Jack Shepherd.

results.title: Escape from sanity: a study of schizophrenia
results.brief_description: A detailed investigation of schizophrenia, the most common form of mental illness, interviewing patients and staff of a psychiatric hospital. Considers the causes of the condition and approaches to treatment and stresses the modern approach - the confrontation situation - based on research in schizophrenics’ families.
